document.docTitle: Messoracarus schwendingeri Kontschán & Seeman, 2012, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Messoracarus (Acari: Mesostigmata: Aenictequoidea: Messoracaridae) from Laos

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Messoracarus (Acari: Mesostigmata: Aenictequoidea: Messoracaridae) from Laos

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
Holotype
. Female, Laos , LT- 10 / 12 , Oudomxai Prov., ca. 3 km E of Tad Lak 11 , SE of Oudomxai (= Muang Xai) city, 2036 ’ 20 ”N, 10201 ’ 16 ”E, 1020 m , primary forest,
18 September 2010
, P. Schwendinger coll. (in NHMG ).
Paratype
. One male in QM, locality and date same as holotype . One male, Laos , LT- 10 / 14 , Oudomxai Prov., trail to Tad Nam Kad, E of Oudomxai (= Muang Xai) city, 2041 ’ 45 ”N, 10206 ’ 45 ”E, 900 m , primary forest,
19 September 2010
, P. Schwendinger coll. ( NHMG ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–3.
Messoracarus schwendingeri
sp. nov.
, female. 1. Dorsal idiosoma; 2. Dorsal shield pattern and setae; 3. Marginal and dorsal setae.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ventral idiosoma (
Figs 4–7
). Sclerotisation extensive, forming large, contiguous shields, with reticulate pattern, and separated by narrow strips of membranous cuticle (
Fig. 4
). Tritosternal base narrow, laciniae fused, marginally and apically serrate (see
Fig. 9
, male). Sternal shield fragmented into five plates, all smooth. Paired presternal plates bearing needle-like setae
st 1
( 16–18 µm) and
stp 1
at posterolateral margins (
Fig. 5
). Anteromedial sternal fragment subtriangular, without setae. Medial sternal fragment fused laterally to endopodal shield, bearing setae
st 2
( 42–44 µm) and stp 2 . Posterior sternal fragment narrow, fused laterally to endopodal shields, extending into genital region medially, bearing one pair of smooth setae (
st 3
), length 23 µm. Endopodal shield smooth and without setae.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 4–6 .
Messoracarus schwendingeri
sp. nov.
, female. 4. Ventral idiosoma; 5. Intercoxal area; 6. Ventrianal area.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gnathosoma
. Same as male. Gnathotectum rounded, with serrate margin (
Fig. 7
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 7–12.
Messoracarus schwendingeri
sp. nov.
7. Gnathotectum of female. 8. Ventral idiosoma of male; 9. Tritosternum of male; 10. Ventral gnathosoma of male; 11. Palp of male; 12. Antaxial (left) and abaxial (right) view of chelicerae of male.

subSubSection.paragraph: Chelicerae . Not seen clearly, but appear same as male. Legs . Same as male.

Gnathosoma
(
Figs 10–11
). Hypostomal setae
h 1 –h 4
smooth and long ( 36–40 µm). Tip of hypostome expanded, with paired membranous flanges. Internal malae with numerous denticles, about as long as corniculi. Paired, tapering medial processes arise above malae and extend beyond their tips. Corniculi lightly sclerotised basally, becoming membranous, with lateral tine and broad denticulate lobes. Palp tibia and tarsus fused, but with partial line of fusion; apotele two-tined. Palp setal formula
2-4 - 7-22
(
Fig. 11
). Fixed digit of chelicera bearing niblike cheliceral seta (
Fig. 12
), developed pilus dentilis, fringe of hairs (in place of teeth), a serrated membranous excrescence; digit terminating in a forked tip; antiaxial surface bearing a membranous lobe with numerous tiny denticles. Movable digit gradually becomes unsclerotised, bearing a hyaline fringed lobe and nine hyaline “teeth, three excrescences (one long and coarsely serrated; one shorter and finely serrated; one very short with few serrations); digit also terminates in a forked tip.

Legs (
Figs 13–16
). Leg I without pretarsus; legs II–IV with claws slender, weakly formed, and well-developed ambulacrum. All setae on legs fine, weakly barbed to smooth. Leg seta counts (coxa-tarsus):
2-5 - 10 - 8 - 8
-40, 2-
5-9 - 8 - 7-19
, 2-
5-7 - 10 - 8-19
, 1-
5-8 - 8 - 7-21
. Chaetotaxy as in
Figs 13–16
. Tarsus I with two very long setae, three thick blunt setae, and a cluster of three short blunt setae. Coxae II–IV with large ventrodistal denticles. Genu and tibia II–IV with large crescent-shaped slit organs (
Fig. 15
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 13–16.
Messoracarus schwendingeri
sp. nov.
, male. 13. Leg I; 14. Leg II; 15. Leg III, with dorsal view of genu and tibia; 16. Leg IV.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. We dedicate the new species to Dr. Peter Schwendinger, who collected these mites.
